Author: PoopTransplant

Comment: Verbiage is not a justification for use of force.  It may not go this way, but this is a textbook example of what is NOT reasonable force.    Town Hall Meetings may become loud, but shouting is NOT use of force (provided that the person is not making threats, of course).  The ONLY justification for a LEO becoming involved is if someone is acting in a way that gives a reasonable person cause to fear for their safety.    Being vocal at a Town Hall Meeting is covered under the First Amendment.  If you don't like what someone is saying (no matter how loudly) you are free to cover your ears.  Sticks & stones are justification for force (or threats of use of sticks & stones & fire etc); words aren't.  The education level of US Law Enforcement is beyond utterly dismal.  They do not seem to have even a remedial level of legal comprehension.

Author: TataraSoul

Comment: I mean, not really? You have the right to express yourself, sure. But most states have a disorderly conduct statute that prohibits conduct that a reasonable person would not find permissable. Generally the law supports action against speech if it regards the unreasonable conduct in which it is expressed versus the content of the speech.  That goes twofold if it's hosted at a location on private property, then you have trespass statutes that can be used as well.

Comment: Yeah, I worked as a security guard and we can't touch someone unless a few factors happen; medical emergency, self-defense or defense of others (breaking up a fight, etc). It's one thing to escort someone out, but dragging them needs to be done by the actual police.  Was this on private property? I can't recall if the article said as much. If you ask someone to leave and they won't,  you can tresspas them. A lot of people don't understand that private property is still private even if owned by a business.
